ticket.title: Adding public options to client-side caching
ticket.original-body:
If you want to use Proxy caches with Rails, you have to modify the "Cache-Control" header to have the public keyword. This is defaulted to private in rails, which is should be. Previously you had to deal with this like so:
@@@ ruby expires_in 10.minutes, :private => false, :public => true
fresh_when :last_modified => @user.updated_at.utc headers['Cache-Control'] = 'public'
fresh_when :etag => @user headers['Cache-Control'] = 'public' @@@
Here is code (with tests) that allows you to do:
@@@ ruby expires_in 10.minutes, :public => true
fresh_when :last_modified => @user.updated_at.utc, :public => true
fresh_when :etag => @user, :public => true @@@
I've also added some additional tests for expires_at that seemed to be missing from the code. For additional explanation, see the "Advanced HTTP Caching Screencast":http://railslab.newrelic.com/2009/02/26/episode-11-advanced-http-caching.
ticket.latest-body:
If you want to use Proxy caches with Rails, you have to modify the "Cache-Control" header to have the public keyword. This is defaulted to private in rails, which is should be. Previously you had to deal with this like so:
@@@ ruby expires_in 10.minutes, :private => false, :public => true
fresh_when :last_modified => @user.updated_at.utc headers['Cache-Control'] = 'public'
fresh_when :etag => @user headers['Cache-Control'] = 'public' @@@
Here is code (with tests) that allows you to do:
@@@ ruby expires_in 10.minutes, :public => true
fresh_when :last_modified => @user.updated_at.utc, :public => true
fresh_when :etag => @user, :public => true @@@
I've also added some additional tests for expires_at that seemed to be missing from the code. For additional explanation, see the "Advanced HTTP Caching Screencast":http://railslab.newrelic.com/2009/02/26/episode-11-advanced-http-caching.
ticket.original-body-html:
If you want to use Proxy caches with Rails, you have to modify the "Cache-Control" header to have the public keyword. This is defaulted to private in rails, which is should be. Previously you had to deal with this like so:


expires_in 10.minutes, :private => false, :public => true
 
fresh_when :last_modified => @user.updated_at.utc
headers['Cache-Control'] = 'public'
 
fresh_when :etag => @user
headers['Cache-Control'] = 'public'

Here is code (with tests) that allows you to do:


expires_in 10.minutes, :public => true
 
fresh_when :last_modified => @user.updated_at.utc, :public => true
 
fresh_when :etag => @user, :public => true

I've also added some additional tests for expires_at that seemed to be missing from the code. For additional explanation, see the Advanced HTTP Caching Screencast.

version.body:
If you want to use Proxy caches with Rails, you have to modify the "Cache-Control" header to have the public keyword. This is defaulted to private in rails, which is fine, but the syntax to set cache-control to public isn't too pretty: @@@ ruby expires_in 10.minutes, :private => false, :public => true
fresh_when :last_modified => @user.updated_at.utc headers['Cache-Control'] = 'public'
fresh_when :etag => @user headers['Cache-Control'] = 'public' @@@
Here is code (with tests) that allows you to do:
@@@ ruby expires_in 10.minutes, :public => true
fresh_when :last_modified => @user.updated_at.utc, :public => true
fresh_when :etag => @user, :public => true @@@
I've also added some additional tests for expires_at that seemed to be missing from the code. For additional explanation, see the "Advanced HTTP Caching Screencast":http://railslab.newrelic.com/2009/02/26/episode-11-advanced-http-caching.
version.body-html:
If you want to use Proxy caches with Rails, you have to modify the "Cache-Control" header to have the public keyword. This is defaulted to private in rails, which is fine, but the syntax to set cache-control to public isn't too pretty:


expires_in 10.minutes, :private => false, :public => true
 
fresh_when :last_modified => @user.updated_at.utc
headers['Cache-Control'] = 'public'
 
fresh_when :etag => @user
headers['Cache-Control'] = 'public'

Here is code (with tests) that allows you to do:


expires_in 10.minutes, :public => true
 
fresh_when :last_modified => @user.updated_at.utc, :public => true
 
fresh_when :etag => @user, :public => true

I've also added some additional tests for expires_at that seemed to be missing from the code. For additional explanation, see the Advanced HTTP Caching Screencast.
version.title: Adding public options to client-side caching

version.body:
(from [f2a32bd0dedf11021027e36cc2c99f97434cae17]) Added ability to pass in :public => true to fresh_when, stale?, and expires_in to make the request proxy cachable [#2095 state:committed]
Signed-off-by: David Heinemeier Hansson <david@loudthinking.com> http://github.com/rails/rails/commit/f2a32bd0dedf11021027e36cc2c99f97434cae17
version.body-html:
(from [f2a32bd0dedf11021027e36cc2c99f97434cae17]) Added ability to pass in :public => true to fresh_when, stale?, and expires_in to make the request proxy cachable [#2095 state:committed]

Signed-off-by: David Heinemeier Hansson david@loudthinking.com http://github.com/rails/rails/co...
version.title: Adding public options to client-side caching

version.body:
Actually, the default Cache-Control seems to be no-cache now, when you use the conditional GET helpers at least. So this patch only helps if you only want public headers.
I'm thinking this patch should be reworked so that you can say :public => false. Which would make it set a Cache-Control header of private, instead of the no-cache default. This is useful if you want the clients to cache it, but not any proxies (assuming they play nice of course).
version.body-html:
Actually, the default Cache-Control seems to be no-cache now, when you use the conditional GET helpers at least. So this patch only helps if you only want public headers.

I'm thinking this patch should be reworked so that you can say :public => false. Which would make it set a Cache-Control header of private, instead of the no-cache default. This is useful if you want the clients to cache it, but not any proxies (assuming they play nice of course).
version.title: Adding public options to client-side caching

version.body:
Due to the fact that this commit introduces two test methods named test_expires_in_header this is never exposed in the tests.
Attached is a patch that renames one of the test methods and fixes the regression.
version.body-html:
Due to the fact that this commit introduces two test methods named test_expires_in_header this is never exposed in the tests.

Attached is a patch that renames one of the test methods and fixes the regression.
version.title: Adding public options to client-side caching
Adding public options to client-side caching

version.body:
(from [c071123b3e2d6fd918dd7e419efe7429355445c2]) Ensure expires_in without a :public key sets the Cache-Control header to private. [#2095 state:resolved]
This fixes a regression introduced in f2a32bd0, which wasn't exposed due to two test methods having the same name.
Signed-off-by: Pratik Naik <pratiknaik@gmail.com> http://github.com/rails/rails/commit/c071123b3e2d6fd918dd7e419efe7429355445c2
version.body-html:
(from [c071123b3e2d6fd918dd7e419efe7429355445c2]) Ensure expires_in without a :public key sets the Cache-Control header to private. [#2095 state:resolved]

This fixes a regression introduced in f2a32bd0, which wasn't exposed due to two test methods having the same name.

Signed-off-by: Pratik Naik pratiknaik@gmail.com http://github.com/rails/rails/co...
version.title: Adding public options to client-side caching

version.body: This supra footwear is called a modern vintage and has been since their introduction in 2003 where they began in Europe. Every supra shoes has some type of ornament, adornment or hardware and is comprised of aged leather that is bought from around the world. These supra uk are culturally engaging and allow for the woman wearing them to be enveloped in luxury.With new cuts and styles and hand stitched shoes, these timberland boots, heels or flats will make every foot look like it stepped out of vintage Hollywood. This timberland shoes have been worn and coveted by many of the most famous females in recent history. One such coach outlet, Jennifer Aniston, wears them in public and at home.This company makes many different unique styles of bags outlet from ankle booties to sandals, pumps, moncler jackets online, platforms and wedges. One louis vuitton bag in particular is ideal for the gothic style sense; it is patent leather and laces up the front of the shaft. There are also zippers on each side, and this shoe offers a flat heel of a half inch.Another great moncler jackets sale is featured in People's Style Watch and is called a platform bootie. This ture religion jeans has a raised panel in front of the ankle as well as a heel that measures 4.5 inches. The front offers a leather bandage appearance and is considered high fashion.
